(Listed Building and Conservation Areas) Act 1990 and Development Plan policies. Section 16 of the Planning (Listed Building and Conservation Areas) Act 1990 states that 'In considering whether to grant planning permission for development which affects a listed building or its setting, the local planning authority or, as the case may be, the Secretary of State shall have special regard to the desirability of preserving the building or its setting or any features of special architectural or historic interest which it possesses.' NPPF provisions: It is one of the core principles of the NPPF that heritage assets should be conserved in a manner appropriate to their significance. Chapter 16 of the National Planning Policy Framework at paragraph 195 sets out that the local planning authority should identify and assess the particular significance of any heritage asset... They should take this assessment into account when considering the impact of a proposal on a heritage asset, to avoid or minimise conflict between the heritage asset's conservation and any aspect of the proposal. Paragraphs 199 to 208 of the NPPF 2021 set out the method for assessing the impact of development proposals on heritage assets. Policy HC1 of the London Plan 2021 and Policies CS8 and DM12 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 echo these requirements.When considering the impact of a proposed development on the significance of a designated heritage asset, great weight should be given to the asset's conservation (and the more important the asset, the greater the weight should be). This is irrespective of whether any potential harm amounts to substantial harm, total loss or less than substantial harm to its significance.This application proposes repair works affecting a Grade II* listed building. The application hereby submitted solely seeks  consent for repair works to the external brickwork by way of repointing with lime mortars where possible of all external elevations of the Hall, removal of all cementitious pointing, mortar patch repairs and replacement of defective elements of brickwork in isolated locations with hand-made clay bricks. No works are proposed internally and no external works are otherwise proposed to those stated above.Historic England advises that in those instances where repair works are proposed which is necessary to sustain the heritage asset, this is normally desirable if: - There is sufficient information to understand comprehensively the impacts of the proposals on the significance of the place; and - The long-term consequences of the proposals can, from experience, be demonstrated to be benign or the proposals are designed so as not to prejudice alternative solutions in the future; and - The proposals are designed to avoid or minimise harm, if actions necessary to sustain particular heritage values tend to conflict. The extent of the repair should typically be limited to what is reasonably necessary to make failing elements sound and capable of continuing to fulfil their intended functions. Repairs to brickwork should accurately match the bond, colour, texture, dimensions and pointing of the original brickwork. Any features such as rubbed brick arches or decorative mouldings should be retained, and where necessary repaired or reinstated. Photographic and written schedules have been submitted as part of the corresponding Listed Building Consent (reference: 21/01457/LBC) which provide a detailed written and photographic record of the existing state of the brickwork, details of its condition and recommended repair methods and materials to each specific elevation.Where historic pointing survives, this should be preserved. Repointing should be restricted to those areas where the existing pointing is substantially decayed. The old mortar should be carefully cut-out with hand tools, as the use of mechanical cutters or disc grinders can be highly damaging. The repair of tuck pointing requires specialist craft skills. It is evident that there are elements of the brickwork which are in a poor state of repair, specifically in respect to delamination and erosion of the brick faces, missing mortar and cracks to pointing. There are also some areas of the elevations which have cementitious pointing, and where lime mortar is in place some bricks have damage caused by efflorescence. Due regard has been had to the proposed extent of the repointing, together with the proposed mortar (i.e. lime mortar) which are both considered appropriate to, and necessary for, the overall repair and improvement to the aesthetic to this heritage asset. A condition is attached to the grant of this planning permission to ensure that the method of repointing is traditionally undertaken by hand and not mechanically. Officers note that a washing method statement has been submitted. This sets out in sufficient detail the method of cleaning to the brickwork and the protective systems in place whilst this is to be carried out. All of the proposed measures are considered to be appropriate to have as little harmful impact to the historic fabric of the building as possible. A condition is attached to the grant of this planning permission to ensure that the method of cleaning is carried out in accordance with the contents of the submitted Method Statement. Taking into consideration the submitted plans, photographs and supplementary heritage information, the proposed repair works to the brickwork are deemed to be appropriate as the least interventionist and most sympathetic approach for the repair which would improve the overall character and appearance of the heritage asset. The proposal would be acceptable and would preserve the character and appearance of the Grade II* Listed Building and would not result in harm to the significance of the non-designated heritage asset of the Old London Road Area of Special Character, having due regard to Section 16 of the Planning (Listed Building and Conservation Area) Act 1990 permission should be granted. Furthermore, it is concluded that the proposal would not harm the heritage asset as per the requirements of the NPPF 2021. RECOMMENDATION:Approve
